RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



Targa Pipeline Mid-Continent, LLC (Facility ID: 100000087979)



ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES:



Targa Pipeline Mid-Continent, LLC (Targa Pipeline) owns and operates the Velma Gas Processing Plant, located in Stephens County, Oklahoma.  The plant is designed to process natural gas and recover liquid products from natural gas by physical separation and cryogenic means.  Both petroleum condensates and natural gas liquids (NGL, also known as Y grade) are recovered from the inlet pipeline gas in this process for off-site sales.

Targa Pipeline's Velma Gas Plant has a long-standing commitment to its workers and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by our efforts in accident prevention, such as training personnel, quality assurance and considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of our process.  Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However, if a release does occur, facility trained personnel will evaluate the situation, and take actions within the capabilities of the facility.  Velma Gas Plant personnel are trained first responders for certain release scenarios involving hydrogen sulfide, but would rely on outside first responders for release scenarios involving flammables.  For all release scenarios, Velma personnel would notify the necessary outside agencies. 



DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE:



The Velma Gas Plant is located one mile west of Velma, Oklahoma on old Highway 7 and operates a variety of processes to produce the following petroleum products and byproducts:



1. Y grade natural gas liquid,

2. Condensate, and

3. Residue (methane) gas.



The above products contain various mixtures of the following hydrocarbons:



a. Methane

b. Ethane

c. Propane

d. Butane

e. Isobutane

f. Pentane

g. Isopentane



The Velma Gas Plant also produces acid gas (containing

hydrogen sulfide) as a byproduct. The acid gas is sent to an underground injection system. 



OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS RESULTS FOR FLAMMABLE SUBSTANCES:



The worst-case scenario (WCS) associated with a release of flammable substances at Velma Gas Plant is a vapor cloud explosion involving 697,698 pounds (lbs) (180,000 gallons) of a flammable mixture contained in two connected processes.  This flammable mixture is contained in one high pressure (V-0050-1-152) product surge vessel and two low pressure product surge vessels (V-0050-1-160 and V-0050-1-160-1) associated with the V-100 plant.  The entire inventory is assumed to release and ignite, resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  Since the facility is located near the town of Velma, the WCS for flammable substances could affect off-site endpoints and nearby public receptors.  Targa Pipeline has numerous controls in place to prevent such a release and to manage its consequences. Passive mitigation measures include an automated plant shutdown system to shut down all engines, plant utilities and move the actuated valves to their fail-safe position, which diverts all incoming gas to the emergency flare system. 



The alternative release scenario (ARS) for the flammable substances at Velma Gas Plant is a vapor cloud explosion resulting from the release of the flammable mixture from two inch holes at the bottom of the surge vessels (558,158 lbs over a 15 minute period).  The release is expected to be isolated by plant operation personnel within 15 minutes or by automated plant shutdown system to shut down all engines, plant utilities and moving actuated valves to their fail-safe position, which diverts all incoming gas to the emergency flare system. 



OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS RESULTS FOR TOXIC SUBSTANCES: 



The WCS associated with a release of a toxic substance at Velma Gas Plant is a pipe rupture at the well head for the acid gas (hydrogen sulfide) underground injection system, between the automatic chec

k valve and the manual valve at the well head. This would release acid gas directly from the two inch well head casing pipe into the air until plant operation personnel could safely and property close the valve or kill the well, which is estimated to take about 24 hours. The well pipeline connects to a large underground reservoir with a resulting worst-case release rate of 1,456 pounds per hour (lb/hr), or 34,945 lbs total of hydrogen sulfide released over the 24-hour period.  Since the facility is located near the town of Velma, the WCS for toxic substances could affect off-site endpoints and nearby public receptors. As discussed later in the summary, the Velma Gas Plant has on-site personnel trained in responding to an acid gas incident. Targa personnel would utilize appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) and have the necessary response equipment on-site to attempt to close off or kill the well release in less than 24 hours.  If an expert third-party response team were to become necessary, 24 hours may be required to kill the well.



The ARS for toxic substances at Velma Gas Plant involves a packer leak within the well bore of the acid gas injection well. Such a leak would cause the casing fluid to eventually drain out through the hole, allowing hydrogen sulfide to enter the well casing.  If the casing head at the surface had a hole or leak, then the hydrogen sulfide could be released to the atmosphere. It was assumed that this scenario would release approximately 416 lb/hr, or 9,986 lbs of hydrogen sulfide over a 24-hour period.    



GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM:



A. Employee Participation



Targa encourages its employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention as follows:



1. Updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information

2. Performing necessary calculations for Process Safety Management (PSM) and the Risk Management Plan (RMP)

3. Maintaining good engineering practic

es

4. Participating as a member of a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) team



Employees have access to all information pertaining to the accident prevention program.



B. Process Safety Information



Targa Pipeline's Velma Gas Plant keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes.  These technical documents address the following:



1. Chemical properties and associated hazards

2. Necessary block flow diagrams of the process

3. Maximum intended inventories

4. Upper and Lower limits of process fixed and rotating equipment

5. Equipment design basis and configuration information

6. Identification of necessary regulatory equipment design documents

7. Sufficient information to assure good engineering practices



The location of the technical documents referenced above is listed in the Process Safety Information portion of the PSM documents.



Chemical specific information, including hazard and emergency response/exposure considerations, is provided in the material safety data sheets (MSDS).  For specific process areas, the facility has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters such as temperatures, level and composition in the operator's procedures manual.  The facility maintains the process within these limits by using process controls and monitoring instruments, trained personnel and protective instrument systems such as automated shutdown systems. 



The facility also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of the process equipment.  This information includes materials of construction, design pressures, temperature and electrical ratings.  This information, in combination with procedures and equipment operating history, provides a basis for inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to safety features. 



C. Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)



The Velma Gas Plant has a

comprehensive program to identify and control hazards associated with the RMP covered processes.  This program systematically examines and explores potential hazards, then establishes controls to manage the potential hazards.  The PHA is conducted using checklists with a team consisting of Targa Pipeline employees who have operation, maintenance, engineering and safety experience.  The team identifies, evaluates and makes recommendations to management regarding potential hazards.  The team's findings are forwarded to Targa Pipeline and Velma Gas Plant Management for resolution.  The approved mitigation options in response to the PHA team's findings are tracked until they are completed.  The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.



The facility periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results.  These periodic reviews are conducted at least every five years and will be conducted at this frequency until the plant is no longer operating.  The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained in Targa Pipeline's records.



D. Operating Procedures



Targa Pipeline's Velma Gas Plant maintains written Operating Procedures of the covered processes that address primary operations mandated by OSHA, EPA, Good Engineering Practice and manufacturers.  These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  Procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as "current and accurate" by management.  The procedures are maintained to be "current and accurate," revising them as necessary by employee suggestion, compliance audit, PHA, Good Engineering Practice and Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) and are implemented through Management of Change.



Covered Process Operating Procedures are readily available to operators in the process unit and to other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job tasks and maintain the covered proce

ss unit operating within its safe limits.



E.  Training



Velma Gas Plant has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating the covered process.  New employees receive basic training in process operations if they are not already familiar with such operations.  After successfully completing this training, a novice operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks.  A performance review and written test specific to the facility operations is administered and must be successfully completed by the novice during this training period.  After the operator demonstrates adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on his or her own, he or she is allowed to work independently.  In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level.  This refresher training is conducted at least every three years, or more frequently upon request.  Training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify and demonstrate skills.



F. Contractors



The Velma Gas Plant uses contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities.  Because some contractors work on or near covered process equipment, the facility has procedures in place to ensure that contractors:



1. Perform their work in a safe manner

2. Have the appropriate knowledge and skills

3. Are aware of the hazards in their workplace

4. Understand what they should do in the event of an emergency

5. Understand and follow site safety rules

6. Inform facility personnel of any hazard that they find during their work



This is accomplished by providing contractors with:



1. A process overview

2. Information about safety and health hazards

3. Emergency Action Plan requirements

4. Safe work practices before beginning work



In addition, Velma Ga

s Plant Management will evaluate the contractor safety program and performance during the selection of a contractor.  Facility personnel periodically monitor contractor performance with regard to their safety obligations. 



G. Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)



Targa Velma Gas Plant conducts a PSSR for any new facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information.  The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup before placing the equipment into service.  This review provides one additional check that construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that supporting systems are operationally ready.  A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and services as quality assurance verification that the accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.



H. Mechanical Integrity



Velma Gas Plant has established practices and procedures for the safe operation of fixed, rotating and emergency shutdown equipment.  The basic aspects of the program include, but are not limited to, the following:



1. Conducting training

2. Developing written procedures

3. Performing inspections and tests

4. Correcting identified deficiencies

5. Applying quality assurance measures



In combination, these activities form a system to maintain the mechanical integrity of the process.



Maintenance personnel receive training on:



1. Overview of the process

2. Safety and Health hazards

3. Applicable maintenance procedures

4. Emergency Action Plan

5. Applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their jobs in a safe manner



Written procedures ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner and serve as a basis for training.  Inspections and tests are performed to help verify that equipment functions as intended and that equipment is within acceptable limits.  If a deficiency is identified and the situat

ion presents an immediate safety concern, the deficiency is corrected before placing the equipment back into service.  A management of change team will review the use of equipment and determine what action is necessary.



An integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance.  Velma Gas Plant incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs.  This helps to determine that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that the proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made. 



I. Safe Work Practices



Velma Gas Plant has long-standing safe work practices as mandated by OSHA, Industrial Standards and Good Engineering Practice in place to help provide employee, public and process safety.



J. Management of Change



Velma Gas Plant has a comprehensive system to manage changes to the RMP-covered processes.  This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology and procedures be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.  Changes are reviewed to:



1. Determine that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards

2. Verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the proposed change



Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits and equipment information and procedures are updated to incorporate these changes.  In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are trained on the changes.



K. Incident Investigation



Velma Gas Plant promptly investigates incidents related to a covered process that result in or could have reasonably resulted in a fire/explosion, property damage, environmental loss or personal injury.  The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and to develop corrective action to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident.  The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent future occurrences and forwards these results to facilit

y management for resolution.  Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are traced until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented and investigation reports are retained for at least five years. 



L. Compliance Audits



At least every three years, a Compliance Audit addressing OSHA, EPA, RMP and Good Engineering Practices are conducted by employees and management of Velma Gas Plant.  This audit team develops findings that are forwarded to facility management for resolution.  Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are completed.  Final resolution of each finding is documented and the two most recent audit reports are retained.  



M. Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



The following is a description of existing features applicable to the prevention of accidental releases of regulated substances in this facility:



Universal Prevention Activities:

Velma's accident release prevention and response policies are applied to RMP-covered processes.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help to prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failure and human errors.



N. Specialized Safety Features



Site specific detection and control equipment (safety features) are deployed throughout the plant to:



1. Contain/control a release

2. Quickly detect a release

3. Reduce the consequences of an RMP-regulated substance release



The following types of safety features are used:



O. Release Detection



1. Hydrocarbon and hydrogen sulfide detectors with alarms



P. Release Containment/Control



1. Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases 

2. Automated and manual valves to permit isolation of the process

3. Automated plant shutdown system to shut down all engines, plant utilities and automatically operate the automatic valves to th

eir fail-safe position, diverting all incoming gas to the emergency flare.

4. Curbing or diking to contain liquids releases

5. Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g. uninterruptible power supply for process control system; backup fire water pumps)

6. Atmospheric relief devices



Q. Release Mitigation



1. Fire suppression and extinguishing system

2. Trained emergency response personnel

3. Personal protective equipment

4. Blast resistant building to help protect control systems and personnel



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



Velma Gas Plant has an excellent record of accident prevention over the past five years.  There have been no accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries or significant property damage on site; and no known off site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damages during this period.



EMERGENCY REPSONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION



Velma Gas Plant is a Non-Responding Facility as per 48 CFR 68.90(b). The plant maintains a written Emergency Action Plan, which is in place to help protect employees and public safety as well as the environment.  The plan identifies steps to be taken in case of an accidental release including: proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation. Also included in the plan is the notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs.



Employees receive training in the procedures to be followed when certain employees must remain to operate critical plant operations before they evacuate. Specifically, the Velma Gas Plant has trained personnel for being the primary responders to an acid gas release. The plant also has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate emergency response organizations (Fire Department, Police and Sheriff's Office) for a release that is outside the plant's response capabilities (i.e. responding to a

large fire, vapor cloud fire, or vapor cloud explosion).  This interface also provides the means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  In addition, Velma Gas Plant conducts periodic emergency drills and annual refresher trainings for plant personnel.
